Appendix PH -A: Conditions
Conditions alter a creature’s capabilities in a variety of ways and can arise as a result of a spell, a class feature, a monster`s attack, or other effect. Mostconditions, such as blinded, are impairments, but a few, such as invisible, can be advantageous.  A condition lasts either until it is countered (the prone condition is countered by standing up, for example) or for a duration specified by the effect that imposed the condition.  If multiple effects impose the same condition on a creature, each instance of the condition has its own duration, but the condition’s effects don’t get worse. A creature either has a condition or doesn’t.  The following definitions specify what happens to a creature while it is subjected to a condition.

Blinded
•A blinded creature can’t see and automatically fails any ability check that requires sight.
•Attack rolls against the creature have advantage,and the creature’s attack rolls have disadvantage.

Charmed
•A charmed creature can’t attack the charmer or target the charmer with harmful abilities or magical effects.
•The charmer has advantage on any ability check to interact socially with the creature.

Deafened
•A deafened creature can’t hear and automatically fails any ability check that requires hearing.

Exhaustion
Some special abilities and environmental hazards, such as starvation and the long--term effects of freezing or scorching temperatures, can lead to a special condition called exhaustion. Exhaustion is measured in six levels. An effect can give a creature one or more levels of exhaustion, as specified in the effect’s description.
Level Effect
1 Disadvantage on ability checks 2 Speed halved 3 Disadvantage on attack rolls and saving throws 4 Hit point maximum halved 5 Speed reduced to 0 6
DeathIf an already exhausted creature suffers another effect that causes exhaustion, its current level of exhaustion increases by the amount specified in the effect’s description.
A creature suffers the effect of its current level of exhaustion as well as all lower levels. For example, a creature suffering level 2 exhaustion has its speed halved and has disadvantage on ability checks.
An effect that removes exhaustion reduces its level as specified in the effect’s description, with all exhaustion effects ending if a creature’s exhaustion level is reduced below 1.
Finishing a long rest reduces a creature’s exhaustion level by 1, provided that the creature has also ingested some food and drink.

Frightened
•A frightened creature has disadvantage on ability checks and attack rolls while the source of its fear is within line of sight.
•The creature can’t willingly move closer to the source of its fear.

Grappled
•A grappled creature’s speed becomes 0, and itcan’t benefit from any bonus to its speed.
•The condition ends if the grappler is incapacitated(see the condition).
•The condition also ends if an effect removes the grappled creature from the reach of the grapple ror grappling effect, such as when a creature is hurled away by the
thunder-wavespell.

Incapacitated
•An incapacitated creature can’t take actions or reactions.

Invisible
•Aninvisible creature is impossible to see without the aid of magic or a special sense. For the purpose of hiding, the creature is heavily obscured. The creature’s location can be detected by any noise it makes or any tracks it leaves.
•Attack rolls against the creature have disadvantage, and the creature’s attack rolls have advantage.

Paralyzed
•A paralyzed creature is incapacitated (see the condition) and can’t move or speak.
•The creature automatically fails Strength andDexterity saving throws.
•Attack rolls against the creature have advantage.
•Any attack that hits the creature is a critical hit ifthe attacker is within 5 feet of the creature.

Petrified
•A petrified creature is transformed, along with any nonmagical object it is wearing or carrying, into a solid inanimate substance (usually stone). Itsweight increases by a factor of ten, and it ceases aging.
•The creature is incapacitated (see the condition),can’t move or speak, and is unaware of its surroundings.
•Attack rolls against the creature have advantage.
•The creature automatically fails Strength andDexterity saving throws.
•The creature has resistance to all damage.
•The creature is immune to poison and disease,although a poison or disease already in its system is suspended, not neutralized.

Poisoned
•A poisoned creature has disadvantage on attack rolls and ability checks.

Prone
•A prone creature’s only movement option is to crawl, unless it stands up and thereby ends the condition.
•The creature has disadvantage on attack rolls.
•An attack roll against the creature has advantage ifthe attacker is within 5 feet of the creature.Otherwise, the attack roll has disadvantage.

Restrained
•A restrained creature’s speed becomes 0, and itcan’t benefit from any bonus to its speed.
•Attack rolls against the creature have advantage,and the creature’s attack rolls have disadvantage.
•The creature has disadvantage on Dexterity saving throws.

Stunned
•A stunned creature is incapacitated (see the condition), can’t move, and can speak onlyfalteringly.
•The creature automatically fails Strength andDexterity saving throws.
•Attack rolls against the creature have advantage.

Unconscious
•An unconscious creature is incapacitated (see the condition), can’t move or speak, and is unaware ofits surroundings
•The creature drops whatever it’s holding and falls prone.
•The creature automatically fails Strength andDexterity saving throws.
•Attack rolls against the creature have advantage.
•Any attack that hits the creature is a critical hit ifthe attacker is within 5 feet of the creature.


Appendix PH -B: Fantasy -Historical Pantheons
The Celtic, Egyptian, Greek, and Norse pantheons are fantasy interpretations of historical religions from our world’s ancient times. They include deities that are most appropriate for use in a game, divorced from their historical context in the real world and united into pantheons that serve the needs of the game.

The Celtic Pantheon
It’s said that something wild lurks in the heart of every soul, a space that thrills to the sound of geese calling at night, to the whispering wind through the pines, to the unexpected red of mistletoe on an oak-and it is in this space that the Celtic gods dwell. They sprang from the brook and stream, their might heightened by the strength of the oak and the beauty of the woodlands and open moor. When the first forester dared put a name to the face seen in the bole of a tree or the voice babbling in a brook, these gods forced themselves into being.  The Celtic gods are as often served by druids as by clerics, for they are closely aligned with the forces of nature that druids revere.

The Greek Pantheon
The gods of Olympus make themselves known with the gentle lap of waves against the shores and the crash of the thunder among the cloud-enshrouded peaks. The thick boar-infested woods and the sere, olive-covered hillsides hold evidence of their passing. Every aspect of nature echoes with their presence, and they’ve made a place for themselves inside the human heart, too.

The Egyptian Pantheon
These gods are a young dynasty of an ancient divine family, heirs to the rulership of the cosmos and the maintenance of the divine principle of Ma’at-the fundamental order of truth, justice, law, and order that puts gods, mortal pharaohs, and ordinary men and women in their logical and rightful place in the universe.
The Egyptian pantheon is unusual in having three gods responsible for death, each with different alignments. Anubis is the lawful neutral god of the afterlife, who judges the souls of the dead. Set is a chaotic evil god of murder, perhaps best known for killing his brother Osiris. And Nephthys is a chaotic good goddess of mourning.

The Norse Pantheon
Where the land plummets from the snowy hills into the icy fjords below, where the longboats draw up on to the beach, where the glaciers flow forward and retreat with every fall and spring-this is the land of the Vikings, the home of the Norse pantheon. It’s a brutal clime, and one that calls for brutal living. The warriors of the land have had to adapt to the harsh conditions in order to survive, but they haven’t been too twisted by the needs of their environment. Given the necessity of raiding for food and wealth, it’s surprising the mortals turned out as well as they did. Their powers reflect the need these warriors had for strong leadership and decisive action. Thus, they see their deities in every bend of a river, hear them in the crash of the thunder and the booming of the glaciers, and smell them in the smoke of a burning longhouse.
The Norse pantheon includes two main families, the Aesir (deities of war and destiny) and the Vanir (gods of fertility and prosperity). Once enemies, these two families are now closely allied against their common enemies, the giants (including the gods Surtur and Thrym).

Appendix PH -C: The Planes of Existence
The cosmos teems with a multitude of worlds as well as myriad alternate dimensions of reality, called the
planes of existence. It encompasses every world where GMs run their adventures, all within the relatively mundane realm of the Material Plane. Beyond that plane are domains of raw elemental matter and energy, realms of pure thought and ethos, the homes of demons and angels, and the dominions of the gods.   Many spells and magic items can draw energy from these planes, summon the creatures that dwell there, communicate with their denizens, and allow adventurers to travel there. As your character achieves greater power and higher levels, you might walk on streets made of solid fire or test your mettle on a battlefield where the fallen are resurrected with each dawn.

The Material Plane
The Material Plane is the nexus where the philosophical and elemental forces that define the other planes collide in the jumbled existence of mortal life and mundane matter. All fantasy gaming worlds exist within the Material Plane, making it the starting point for most campaigns and adventures. The rest of the multiverse is defined in relation to the Material Plane.  The worlds of the Material Plane are infinitely diverse, for they reflect the creative imagination of the GMs who set their games there, as well as the players whose heroes adventure there. They include magic-wasted desert planets and island-dotted water worlds, worlds where magic combines with advanced technology and others trapped in an endless Stone Age, worlds where the gods walk and places they have abandoned.

Beyond the Material
Beyond the Material Plane, the various planes of existence are realms of myth and mystery. They’re not simply other worlds, but different qualities of being, formed and governed by spiritual and elemental principles abstracted from the ordinary world.

Planar Travel
When adventurers travel into other planes of existence, they are undertaking a legendary journey across the thresholds of existence to a mythic destination where they strive to complete their quest. Such a journey is the stuff of legend. Braving the realms of the dead, seeking out the celestial servants of a deity, or bargaining with an efreeti in its home city will be the subject of song and story for years to come.
Travel to the planes beyond the Material Plane can be accomplished in two ways: by casting a spell or by using a planar portal.
Spells. A number of spells allow direct or indirect access to other planes of existence.
Plane shiftand
gatecan transport adventurers directly to any other plane of existence, with different degrees of precision.
Etherealnessallows adventurers to enter the Ethereal Plane and travel from there to any of the planes it touches-such as the Elemental Planes. And the
astral projectionspell lets adventurers project themselves into the Astral Plane and travel to the Outer Planes.

Portals.A portal is a general term for a stationary interplanar connection that links a specific location on one plane to a specific location on another. Some portals are like doorways, a clear window, or a fog-shrouded passage, and simply stepping through it effects the interplanar travel. Others are locations-circles of standing stones, soaring towers, sailing ships, or even whole towns-that exist in multiple planes at once or flicker from one plane to another in turn. Some are vortices, typically joining an Elemental Plane with a very similar location on the Material Plane, such as the heart of a volcano (leading to the Plane of Fire) or the depths of the ocean (to the Plane of Water).

Transitive Planes
The Ethereal Plane and the Astral Plane are called the Transitive Planes. They are mostly featureless realms that serve primarily as ways to travel from one plane to another. Spells such as
etherealnessand
astral projectionallow characters to enter these planes and traverse them to reach the planes beyond.
The

Ethereal Planeis a misty, fog-bound dimension that is sometimes described as a great ocean. Its shores, called the Border Ethereal, overlap the Material Plane and the Inner Planes, so that every location on those planes has a corresponding location on the Ethereal Plane. Certain creatures can see into the Border Ethereal, and the
see invisibility
and true seeing spell grant that ability. Some magical effects also extend from the Material Plane into the Border Ethereal, particularly effects that use force energy such as force cage and wall of force. The depths of the plane, the Deep Ethereal, are a region of swirling mists and colorful fogs.  The
Astral Plane is the realm of thought and dream, where visitors travel as disembodied souls to reach the planes of the divine and demonic. It is a great, silvery sea, the same above and below, with swirling wisps of white and gray streaking among motes of light resembling distant stars. Erratic whirlpools of color flicker in midair like spinning coins. Occasionalbits of solid matter can be found here, but most of the Astral Plane is an endless, open domain.

Inner Planes
The Inner Planes surround and enfold the Material Plane and its echoes, providing the raw elemental substance from which all the worlds were made. The four
Elemental Planes-Air, Earth, Fire, and Water-form a ring around the Material Plane, suspended within the churning
Elemental Chaos.  At their innermost edges, where they are closest to the Material Plane (in a conceptual if not a literal geographical sense), the four Elemental Planes resemble a world in the Material Plane. The four elements mingle together as they do in the Material Plane, forming land, sea, and sky. Farther from the Material Plane, though, the Elemental Planes are both alien and hostile. Here, the elements exist in their purest form-great expanses of solid earth, blazing fire, crystal-clear water, and unsullied air. These regions are little-known, so when discussing the Plane of Fire, for example, a speaker usually means just the border region. At the farthest extents of the Inner Planes, the pure elements dissolve and bleed together into an unending tumult of clashing energies and colliding substance, the Elemental Chaos.

Outer Planes
If the Inner Planes are the raw matter and energy that makes up the multiverse, the Outer Planes are the direction, thought and purpose for such construction. Accordingly, many sages refer to the Outer Planes as divine planes, spiritual planes, or godly planes, for the Outer Planes are best known as the homes of deities.   When discussing anything to do with deities, the language used must be highly metaphorical. Their actual homes are not literally “places” at all, but exemplify the idea that the Outer Planes are realms of thought and spirit. As with the Elemental Planes, one can imagine the perceptible part of the Outer Planes as a sort of border region, while extensive spiritual regions lie beyond ordinary sensory experience.
Even in those perceptible regions, appearances can be deceptive. Initially, many of the Outer Planes appear hospitable and familiar to natives of the Material Plane. But the landscape can change at the whims of the powerful forces that live on the Outer Planes. The desires of the mighty forces that dwell on these planes can remake them completely, effectively erasing and rebuilding existence itself to better fulfill their own needs.
Distance is a virtually meaningless concept on the Outer Planes. The perceptible regions of the planes often seem quite small, but they can also stretch on to what seems like infinity. It might be possible to take a guided tour of the Nine Hells, from the first layer to the ninth, in a single day-if the powers of the Hells desire it. Or it could take weeks for travelers to make a grueling trek across a single layer.
The most well-known Outer Planes are a group of sixteen planes that correspond to the eight alignments (excluding neutrality) and the shades of distinction between them.

Outer Planes
The planes with some element of good in their nature are called the
Upper Planes. Celestial creatures such as angels and pegasi dwell in the Upper Planes. Planes with some element of evil are the
Lower Planes. Fiends such as demons and devils dwell in the Lower Planes. A plane’s alignment is its essence, and a character whose alignment doesn’t match the plane’s experiences a profound sense of dissonance there. When a good creature visits Elysium, for example (a neutral good Upper Plane), it feels in tune with the plane, but an evil creature feels out of tune and more than a little uncomfortable.

Demiplanes
Demiplanes are small extradimensional spaces with their own unique rules. They are pieces of reality that don’t seem to fit anywhere else. Demiplanes come into being by a variety of means. Some are created by spells, such as
demiplane,or generated at the desire of a powerful deity or other force. They may exist naturally, as a fold of existing reality that
has been pinched off from the rest of the multiverse, or as a baby universe growing in power. A given demiplane can be entered through a single point where it touches another plane. Theoretically, a plane shift spell can also carry travelers to a demiplane, but the proper frequency required for the tuning fork is extremely hard to acquire. The gate spell is more reliable, assuming the caster knows of the demiplane.

Appendix PH -B: Fantasy -Historical Pantheons
The Celtic, Egyptian, Greek, and Norse pantheons are fantasy interpretations of historical religions from our world’s ancient times. They include deities that are most appropriate for use in a game, divorced from their historical context in the real world and united into pantheons that serve the needs of the game.

The Celtic Pantheon
It’s said that something wild lurks in the heart of every soul, a space that thrills to the sound of geese calling at night, to the whispering wind through the pines, to the unexpected red of mistletoe on an oak-and it is in this space that the Celtic gods dwell. They sprang from the brook and stream, their might heightened by the strength of the oak and the beauty of the woodlands and open moor. When the first forester dared put a name to the face seen in the bole of a tree or the voice babbling in a brook, these gods forced themselves into being.  The Celtic gods are as often served by druids as by clerics, for they are closely aligned with the forces of nature that druids revere.

The Greek Pantheon
The gods of Olympus make themselves known with the gentle lap of waves against the shores and the crash of the thunder among the cloud-enshrouded peaks. The thick boar-infested woods and the sere, olive-covered hillsides hold evidence of their passing. Every aspect of nature echoes with their presence, and they’ve made a place for themselves inside the human heart, too.

The Egyptian Pantheon
These gods are a young dynasty of an ancient divine family, heirs to the rulership of the cosmos and the maintenance of the divine principle of Ma’at-the fundamental order of truth, justice, law, and order that puts gods, mortal pharaohs, and ordinary men and women in their logical and rightful place in the universe.
The Egyptian pantheon is unusual in having three gods responsible for death, each with different alignments. Anubis is the lawful neutral god of the afterlife, who judges the souls of the dead. Set is a chaotic evil god of murder, perhaps best known for killing his brother Osiris. And Nephthys is a chaotic good goddess of mourning.

The Norse Pantheon
Where the land plummets from the snowy hills into the icy fjords below, where the longboats draw up on to the beach, where the glaciers flow forward and retreat with every fall and spring-this is the land of the Vikings, the home of the Norse pantheon. It’s a brutal clime, and one that calls for brutal living. The warriors of the land have had to adapt to the harsh conditions in order to survive, but they haven’t been too twisted by the needs of their environment. Given the necessity of raiding for food and wealth, it’s surprising the mortals turned out as well as they did. Their powers reflect the need these warriors had for strong leadership and decisive action. Thus, they see their deities in every bend of a river, hear them in the crash of the thunder and the booming of the glaciers, and smell them in the smoke of a burning longhouse.
The Norse pantheon includes two main families, the Aesir (deities of war and destiny) and the Vanir (gods of fertility and prosperity). Once enemies, these two families are now closely allied against their common enemies, the giants (including the gods Surtur and Thrym).

Appendix PH -C: The Planes of Existence
The cosmos teems with a multitude of worlds as well as myriad alternate dimensions of reality, called the
planes of existence. It encompasses every world where GMs run their adventures, all within the relatively mundane realm of the Material Plane. Beyond that plane are domains of raw elemental matter and energy, realms of pure thought and ethos, the homes of demons and angels, and the dominions of the gods.   Many spells and magic items can draw energy from these planes, summon the creatures that dwell there, communicate with their denizens, and allow adventurers to travel there. As your character achieves greater power and higher levels, you might walk on streets made of solid fire or test your mettle on a battlefield where the fallen are resurrected with each dawn.

The Material Plane
The Material Plane is the nexus where the philosophical and elemental forces that define the other planes collide in the jumbled existence of mortal life and mundane matter. All fantasy gaming worlds exist within the Material Plane, making it the starting point for most campaigns and adventures. The rest of the multiverse is defined in relation to the Material Plane.  The worlds of the Material Plane are infinitely diverse, for they reflect the creative imagination of the GMs who set their games there, as well as the players whose heroes adventure there. They include magic-wasted desert planets and island-dotted water worlds, worlds where magic combines with advanced technology and others trapped in an endless Stone Age, worlds where the gods walk and places they have abandoned.

Beyond the Material
Beyond the Material Plane, the various planes of existence are realms of myth and mystery. They’re not simply other worlds, but different qualities of being, formed and governed by spiritual and elemental principles abstracted from the ordinary world.

Planar Travel
When adventurers travel into other planes of existence, they are undertaking a legendary journey across the thresholds of existence to a mythic destination where they strive to complete their quest. Such a journey is the stuff of legend. Braving the realms of the dead, seeking out the celestial servants of a deity, or bargaining with an efreeti in its home city will be the subject of song and story for years to come.
Travel to the planes beyond the Material Plane can be accomplished in two ways: by casting a spell or by using a planar portal.
Spells. A number of spells allow direct or indirect access to other planes of existence.
Plane shiftand
gatecan transport adventurers directly to any other plane of existence, with different degrees of precision.
Etherealnessallows adventurers to enter the Ethereal Plane and travel from there to any of the planes it touches-such as the Elemental Planes. And the
astral projectionspell lets adventurers project themselves into the Astral Plane and travel to the Outer Planes.

Portals.A portal is a general term for a stationary interplanar connection that links a specific location on one plane to a specific location on another. Some portals are like doorways, a clear window, or a fog-shrouded passage, and simply stepping through it effects the interplanar travel. Others are locations-circles of standing stones, soaring towers, sailing ships, or even whole towns-that exist in multiple planes at once or flicker from one plane to another in turn. Some are vortices, typically joining an Elemental Plane with a very similar location on the Material Plane, such as the heart of a volcano (leading to the Plane of Fire) or the depths of the ocean (to the Plane of Water).

Transitive Planes
The Ethereal Plane and the Astral Plane are called the Transitive Planes. They are mostly featureless realms that serve primarily as ways to travel from one plane to another. Spells such as
etherealnessand
astral projectionallow characters to enter these planes and traverse them to reach the planes beyond.
The

Ethereal Planeis a misty, fog-bound dimension that is sometimes described as a great ocean. Its shores, called the Border Ethereal, overlap the Material Plane and the Inner Planes, so that every location on those planes has a corresponding location on the Ethereal Plane. Certain creatures can see into the Border Ethereal, and the
see invisibility
and true seeing spell grant that ability. Some magical effects also extend from the Material Plane into the Border Ethereal, particularly effects that use force energy such as force cage and wall of force. The depths of the plane, the Deep Ethereal, are a region of swirling mists and colorful fogs.  The
Astral Plane is the realm of thought and dream, where visitors travel as disembodied souls to reach the planes of the divine and demonic. It is a great, silvery sea, the same above and below, with swirling wisps of white and gray streaking among motes of light resembling distant stars. Erratic whirlpools of color flicker in midair like spinning coins. Occasionalbits of solid matter can be found here, but most of the Astral Plane is an endless, open domain.

Inner Planes
The Inner Planes surround and enfold the Material Plane and its echoes, providing the raw elemental substance from which all the worlds were made. The four
Elemental Planes-Air, Earth, Fire, and Water-form a ring around the Material Plane, suspended within the churning
Elemental Chaos.  At their innermost edges, where they are closest to the Material Plane (in a conceptual if not a literal geographical sense), the four Elemental Planes resemble a world in the Material Plane. The four elements mingle together as they do in the Material Plane, forming land, sea, and sky. Farther from the Material Plane, though, the Elemental Planes are both alien and hostile. Here, the elements exist in their purest form-great expanses of solid earth, blazing fire, crystal-clear water, and unsullied air. These regions are little-known, so when discussing the Plane of Fire, for example, a speaker usually means just the border region. At the farthest extents of the Inner Planes, the pure elements dissolve and bleed together into an unending tumult of clashing energies and colliding substance, the Elemental Chaos.

Outer Planes
If the Inner Planes are the raw matter and energy that makes up the multiverse, the Outer Planes are the direction, thought and purpose for such construction. Accordingly, many sages refer to the Outer Planes as divine planes, spiritual planes, or godly planes, for the Outer Planes are best known as the homes of deities.   When discussing anything to do with deities, the language used must be highly metaphorical. Their actual homes are not literally “places” at all, but exemplify the idea that the Outer Planes are realms of thought and spirit. As with the Elemental Planes, one can imagine the perceptible part of the Outer Planes as a sort of border region, while extensive spiritual regions lie beyond ordinary sensory experience.
Even in those perceptible regions, appearances can be deceptive. Initially, many of the Outer Planes appear hospitable and familiar to natives of the Material Plane. But the landscape can change at the whims of the powerful forces that live on the Outer Planes. The desires of the mighty forces that dwell on these planes can remake them completely, effectively erasing and rebuilding existence itself to better fulfill their own needs.
Distance is a virtually meaningless concept on the Outer Planes. The perceptible regions of the planes often seem quite small, but they can also stretch on to what seems like infinity. It might be possible to take a guided tour of the Nine Hells, from the first layer to the ninth, in a single day-if the powers of the Hells desire it. Or it could take weeks for travelers to make a grueling trek across a single layer.
The most well-known Outer Planes are a group of sixteen planes that correspond to the eight alignments (excluding neutrality) and the shades of distinction between them.

Outer Planes
The planes with some element of good in their nature are called the
Upper Planes. Celestial creatures such as angels and pegasi dwell in the Upper Planes. Planes with some element of evil are the
Lower Planes. Fiends such as demons and devils dwell in the Lower Planes. A plane’s alignment is its essence, and a character whose alignment doesn’t match the plane’s experiences a profound sense of dissonance there. When a good creature visits Elysium, for example (a neutral good Upper Plane), it feels in tune with the plane, but an evil creature feels out of tune and more than a little uncomfortable.

Demiplanes
Demiplanes are small extradimensional spaces with their own unique rules. They are pieces of reality that don’t seem to fit anywhere else. Demiplanes come into being by a variety of means. Some are created by spells, such as
demiplane,or generated at the desire of a powerful deity or other force. They may exist naturally, as a fold of existing reality that
has been pinched off from the rest of the multiverse, or as a baby universe growing in power. A given demiplane can be entered through a single point where it touches another plane. Theoretically, a plane shift spell can also carry travelers to a demiplane, but the proper frequency required for the tuning fork is extremely hard to acquire. The gate spell is more reliable, assuming the caster knows of the demiplane.

**What happens when a creature is grappled?**

1. **Speed and movement** – The grappled creature’s speed is reduced to 0.  
   *It can’t benefit from any bonus to its speed and it can’t move out of the grappler’s reach unless it is forcibly moved.*

2. **Attack actions** – The creature may not use the Attack action **unless** it is attacking the grappler.

3. **Escaping** – The grappled creature can use an **action** (not a bonus action) to try to escape.  
   - It makes an **Athletics** or **Acrobatics** check.  
   - On a success, the grapple ends and the creature is free.

4. **Moving** – If either the grappler or the grappled creature moves more than 5 feet from the other (e.g., by moving or being shoved), the grapple ends automatically.

5. **Incapacitation / death** – If either creature is **incapacitated** (or dies), the grapple ends immediately.

6. **Forced out of reach** – If an effect (spell, push, teleport, etc.) forces a creature out of the grappler’s reach, the grapple ends.

7. **Special features** – Some abilities or spells (e.g., a monk’s *Stunning Strike*, a spell that “breaks” grapples) explicitly end grapples.

**Duration**

- There is **no fixed time limit**; a grapple continues until one of the above ending conditions occurs.

**Summary**

A grappled creature’s speed is 0, it can’t attack except against the grappler, and it may attempt to escape with an action. The grapple ends when the creature successfully escapes, when either creature is incapacitated or dies, when either creature moves more than 5 feet away, when the creature is forced out of reach, or when an effect that breaks grapples is applied.

**Paralyzed (5e)** – A creature that is paralyzed is **incapacitated**.  
That means:

| Effect | What the creature can’t do | What it still can do |
|--------|---------------------------|----------------------|
| **Actions / Reactions** | Cannot take any actions, bonus actions, or reactions. | It can still speak, shout, or make noises. |
| **Movement** | Cannot move or be moved. | It can be moved by effects that override the condition. |
| **Saving Throws** | Automatically fails Strength and Dexterity saving throws. | It can still be forced to make saves by spells/effects that target it. |
| **Being Attacked** | Attack rolls against it have advantage. | Any attack that hits is a **critical hit** if the attacker is within 5 feet. |

So, a paralyzed creature essentially sits or lies still, can’t act or react, but can still be targeted, speak, and is highly vulnerable to melee attacks.

reference_contexts: Appendix PH -B: Fantasy -Historical Pantheons The Celtic, Egyptian, Greek, and Norse pantheons are fantasy interpretations of historical religions from our world’s ancient times. They include deities that are most appropriate for use in a game, divorced from their historical context in the real world and united into pantheons that serve the needs of the game. The Celtic Pantheon It’s said that something wild lurks in the heart of every soul, a space that thrills to the sound of geese calling at night, to the whispering wind through the pines, to the unexpected red of mistletoe on an oak-and it is in this space that the Celtic gods dwell. They sprang from the brook and stream, their might heightened by the strength of the oak and the beauty of the woodlands and open moor. When the first forester dared put a name to the face seen in the bole of a tree or the voice babbling in a brook, these gods forced themselves into being. The Celtic gods are as often served by druids as by clerics, for they are closely aligned with the forces of nature that druids revere. The Greek Pantheon The gods of Olympus make themselves known with the gentle lap of waves against the shores and the crash of the thunder among the cloud-enshrouded peaks. The thick boar-infested woods and the sere, olive-covered hillsides hold evidence of their passing. Every aspect of nature echoes with their presence, and they’ve made a place for themselves inside the human heart, too. The Egyptian Pantheon These gods are a young dynasty of an ancient divine family, heirs to the rulership of the cosmos and the maintenance of the divine principle of Ma’at-the fundamental order of truth, justice, law, and order that puts gods, mortal pharaohs, and ordinary men and women in their logical and rightful place in the universe. The Egyptian pantheon is unusual in having three gods responsible for death, each with different alignments. Anubis is the lawful neutral god of the afterlife, who judges the souls of the dead. Set is a chaotic evil god of murder, perhaps best known for killing his brother Osiris. And Nephthys is a chaotic good goddess of mourning. The Norse Pantheon Where the land plummets from the snowy hills into the icy fjords below, where the longboats draw up on to the beach, where the glaciers flow forward and retreat with every fall and spring-this is the land of the Vikings, the home of the Norse pantheon. It’s a brutal clime, and one that calls for brutal living. The warriors of the land have had to adapt to the harsh conditions in order to survive, but they haven’t been too twisted by the needs of their environment. Given the necessity of raiding for food and wealth, it’s surprising the mortals turned out as well as they did. Their powers reflect the need these warriors had for strong leadership and decisive action. Thus, they see their deities in every bend of a river, hear them in the crash of the thunder and the booming of the glaciers, and smell them in the smoke of a burning longhouse. The Norse pantheon includes two main families, the Aesir (deities of war and destiny) and the Vanir (gods of fertility and prosperity). Once enemies, these two families are now closely allied against their common enemies, the giants (including the gods Surtur and Thrym). ### Narrative Description  
The brown bear is a hulking, shag‑covered beast that towers above most other woodland creatures. Its broad shoulders and deep, resonant growl command respect. While its eyes gleam with a calm, animalistic intelligence, its mind is devoted almost entirely to the hunt. The bear’s keen sense of smell can track prey across great distances, and its powerful claws are capable of rending logs and limbs alike. When a brown bear attacks, it moves with an unsettling swiftness, using its massive limbs to unleash a deadly multi‑attack that can sap even a well‑trained ranger’s stamina.

---

### Combat Actions

|--------|--------|-------|--------|-------|
| **Multiattack** | 2 claws | +5 | 6 (1d6 + 4) slashing each | Two attacks per round |

*(The bear’s “Keen Smell” trait gives it advantage on Wisdom (Perception) checks that rely on smell, and it has advantage on any attack that relies on scent, such as a surprise attack against a creature that has not yet noticed it.)*

---

## Storyteller’s Guide: Using Keen Smell & Multi‑Attack in a Wilderness Encounter  

1. **Set the Stage with Scent**  
   * **Trail** – Drop a subtle scent trail (e.g., the faint smell of a wounded deer, or a campfire’s smoke). Allow the party to notice it early on a skill check (Survival + Perception).  
   * **Ambush** – Have the bear detect the trail from a distance, giving the players a window to decide whether to investigate or keep moving. The bear’s keen smell can grant it advantage on a surprise attack if the party enters the bear’s territory without first noticing the scent.

2. **Create Tension Through Movement**  
   * **Ambush Tactics** – Describe the bear leaping from the underbrush, its massive paws crushing bark as it closes in. The players must react quickly; a missed reaction could let the bear use its first Multiattack before they can position themselves.
   * **Environmental Hazards** – The bear’s sudden movement can scatter leaves, trip hikers, or crush a branch into a path. This adds a layer of danger beyond the bear’s attack rolls.

3. **Use the Multi‑Attack to Amplify Fear**  
   * **Overwhelming Force** – After the first claw strike, the bear often follows with a swift bite. Illustrate the roar of the bear and the crunch of flesh to convey how the creature can strike twice before the party can regain footing.  
   * **Target Selection** – Encourage the bear to focus on the most vulnerable party members (e.g., a wounded ranger or a spellcaster whose concentration might be broken). The DM can narrate how the bear’s claws target a specific limb or the bite targets a throat, adding drama.

4. **Provide a Moral Choice**  
   * **Non‑combat Option** – Since the bear is a natural predator, give the party the option to try to flee, distract, or use the terrain to avoid the multi‑attack.  
   * **Negotiation** – If the party has an animal companion or a druidic bond, they might attempt a Wisdom (Animal Handling) check to pacify or redirect the bear, leveraging its natural fear of larger predators or its instinct to protect the young.

5. **Conclude with a Lasting Impact**  
   * **Scent Remains** – Even after the bear leaves, its lingering scent can haunt the party, making subsequent travel in the area more perilous.  
   * **Reputation** – News of the encounter can spread among nearby villages, altering the local perception of the wilderness or prompting future adventures to hunt the “dangerous brown bear.”

---

### Quick Tips for the DM  
- **Use descriptive language** that emphasizes the bear’s smell (“a rich, earthy odor rolls across the wind”) to keep the scent mechanic vivid.  
- **Let the players’ Survival/Perception checks feel meaningful**; a success can give them a chance to set up a defensive position or plan an escape route.  
- **Balance the Multiattack** by ensuring the bear’s damage isn’t trivial—each hit should feel threatening, especially to a party lacking heavy armor or ranged options.

With these elements, the brown bear becomes more than a stat block; it becomes a memorable, scent‑driven adversary that tests both the party’s combat skill and their ability to read the wild’s subtle cues.

**Blink Dog (5th‑level Conjuration, 5e)**  
When you cast *blink dog*, the spectral hound appears in a space you choose. While it’s present it has the following key mechanics:

| Feature | What it does | How it works |
|---------|--------------|--------------|
| **Teleport** | Moves the dog up to **30 feet** as part of its movement. | The dog can teleport *any distance* up to 30 ft. (It doesn’t have to use the full 30 ft.) The destination must be a space the dog can see and must be unoccupied. The teleport is instantaneous; it does **not** provoke opportunity attacks and it doesn’t count as an attack. |
| **Bite** | A melee attack that can be made after the teleport (or before, if you choose). | The dog’s Bite attack is a separate Attack action. It deals **1d4 + 2** piercing damage and has a reach of 5 ft. The dog can only bite once per Attack action (unless it has extra attacks). |

### What happens during a turn?

1. **Movement** – The dog may move up to its speed (40 ft.).  
   *If the dog moves more than 30 ft.*, it can teleport the rest of its movement, up to 30 ft.  
   *If the dog moves less than 30 ft.*, it may still teleport a portion of that movement, as long as the total teleport distance doesn’t exceed 30 ft.  

2. **Teleport** – The teleport is part of the movement, not an action. The dog simply appears in the new space.

3. **Attack** – After moving/teleporting, the dog can use its Attack action to bite (or any other attack it has, e.g., if you granted it extra attacks).  

4. **Other actions** – The dog can perform any other actions allowed (e.g., if you gave it a bonus action attack or a special effect).

### Can it bite *before* teleporting?

Yes. The dog could move a short distance (or none), then bite, and then teleport (if it has remaining movement). However, the teleport itself cannot be used as a bite; the bite is always a separate action.

### Can it bite *after* teleporting?

Yes. Once the dog has finished its movement and teleport, it can still use its Attack action to bite, provided it ends its movement adjacent to a creature (or uses the bite’s 5‑ft reach).

### Summary

- The dog can teleport up to **30 ft** each turn as part of its movement.  
- The teleport is instantaneous and does not count as an attack.  
- The dog can bite **before or after** teleporting, but the bite is always part of its Attack action (not part of the teleport).  

Feel free to let me know if you’re using a different edition or have a specific scenario in mind!

### Giant Spiders in *Dungeons & Dragons* (5th Edition)

| Trait | What it means |
|-------|---------------|
| **AC** 14 | A decent armor class for a creature that relies on stealth and webbing. |
| **HP** 26 | A few hit points; not meant to be tough, but they can be dangerous in groups. |
| **Speed** 30 ft., **climb** 40 ft. | They can easily climb walls and ceilings, making them unpredictable. |
| **STR 12, DEX 15, CON 12, INT 2, WIS 10, CHA 4** | Physical, not mental; they act purely on instinct. |
| **Skills**: Stealth +8, Perception +2 | Silent and very good at hiding. |
| **Senses**: Darkvision 60 ft., passive Perception 12 | They see in dim light and can detect vibrations. |
| **Languages**: — | They communicate only by body language. |
| **Challenge** 1 | A typical low‑level encounter. |
| **Abilities** |  |
| • **Poisoned Bite** | The spider’s bite is a melee weapon attack that deals 1d6+3 piercing + 1d6 poison. The target must succeed on a DC 11 Constitution save or be poisoned (DC 13, 1 minute). |
| • **Web Attack** | Ranged 20 ft./25 ft. (proficiency bonus). The spider can cover a 20‑ft. square in web. Each creature in the web must succeed on a DC 11 Strength save or be restrained (escape 5 ft. each round). Webs are ignored by the spider for movement and can be torn down with an action. |

#### Typical Tactics
1. **Ambush** – Giant spiders wait in or near webs, striking from the shadows.  
2. **Web‑First** – On the first round they often spread a web to trap the party, then use their bite attack to finish off restrained foes.  
3. **Mobility** – With a climb speed, they can escape, reposition, or attack from ceilings.  
4. **Group Coordination** – In packs they can swarm, using webs to separate the party and then bite.  
5. **Poison Focus** – Their bite’s poison can be a big threat to PCs that have low Con or are already wounded.

#### Encounter Tips for the DM
- **Use terrain** – Place webs near chokepoints, stairs, or in cavern ceilings.  
- **Vary tactics** – Mix solo spidies with a few that form a web network.  
- **Add stakes** – If the party is in a ruined building, the spider’s webs can trap the entire floor.  
- **Reward careful players** – A creature with a web attack that can be destroyed with a fire‑based attack or a successful Dexterity check (e.g., a rope to pull down the web) gives players tactical choices.

#### Quick Summary
Giant spiders are stealthy, web‑based ambushers that use their bite’s poison to incapacitate foes. They are most dangerous in groups, using webs to restrain and then bite, and can climb walls and ceilings to change the battlefield. In a 5e encounter, they’re a solid challenge for 1–3 level‑3 characters.
reference: A Giant Spider is a Large beast that lives underground, building its lair on ceilings or in dark, web‑filled crevices. It can climb difficult surfaces, including upside‑down on ceilings, without needing an ability check. The spider spins elaborate webs or shoots sticky strands from its abdomen, using them to snare prey. When it attacks, it bites with a +5 to hit, dealing 7 (1d8+3) piercing damage and forcing a DC 11 Constitution saving throw; on a failed save the target takes 9 (2d8) poison damage. If the poison reduces the target to 0 hit points, the target is stable but poisoned for 1 hour and is paralyzed while poisoned. The spider can also fire a web as a ranged attack (range 30/60 ft.) that restrains the target; the restrained creature can attempt a DC 12 Strength check to burst the web. The webbing itself has AC 10, 5 hit points, is vulnerable to fire damage, and is immune to bludgeoning, poison, and psychic damage. The Giant Spider’s lair is often festooned with web cocoons holding past victims, making it a foreboding, sticky trap for any who dare enter its underground domain.

The Giant Shark has no special abilities beyond those listed, no spellcasting, and no extra attacks.  

---

### How it Behaves & Fights

- **Natural Predator:** Hunts by scent in murky waters, stalking prey before delivering a crushing bite.  
- **Water‑Bound:** Requires water to move and breathe; will not surface to breathe air.  
- **Simple Combat Style:** One bite per round, using its swimming speed to reposition or chase fleeing foes. It rarely charges—most of its energy is spent in pursuit or in ambush.  
- **Tactics for Low‑Level Parties:**  
  1. **Ambush from the Depths** – the shark can appear from a submerged cavern or a hidden trench.  
  2. **Chase & Bait** – it can chase a wounded target until the party’s spellcasters or rangers can finish it off.  
  3. **Harassment** – a single bite can be enough to reduce a party’s hit points; keep the shark at a distance if you’re under‑powered.  

---

### Breathing & Environment

- **Water Breathing:** The shark can stay underwater indefinitely; it does not need to surface for air.  
- **Preferred Habitat:** Deep sea, shallow coastal waters, and large rivers where it can stalk fish or small sea‑folk.

---

### Challenge Rating & Scaling

- **CR ½** – appropriate for a low‑level encounter (levels 1–2).  
- **Scaling Up:**  
  - **Great White Shark (CR 3)** is a step up, with a 2d10 + 3 bite.  
  - **Giant Shark (3.5 e, CR 3)** has 2d10 + 3 bite and a “Giant” special ability (e.g., “Swallow Small Creature”).  
  - For a higher‑level threat, add actions such as a “Rake” (1d4 + 2) or a “Bite” that deals extra damage to a stunned target.

---

### Using a Giant Shark in Your Campaign

| Scenario | Why It Works |
|----------|--------------|
| **Sea‑Travel Hazard** | Random encounter on a voyage; adds danger to naval settings. |
| **Underwater Dungeon** | Guards a submerged cavern or treasure hoard; can be a boss or a minion. |
| **Fisherman’s Legend** | NPCs warn of a “giant shark” that preys on fishermen; can inspire quests to find its lair. |
| **Mount/Companion** | In a world of merfolk or aquatic rangers, a trained shark could serve as a mount. |
| **Environmental Puzzle** | The party must out‑maneuver a shark to reach a submerged portal. |
| **Story Hook** | The party is hired to hunt the shark that has been attacking a nearby fishing village. |

**Creative Twist Ideas**

- **Corrupted Giant Shark:** After a necromancer’s spell, it gains a *Paralyzing Bite* (adds a short‑duration paralysis).  
- **Shark‑Infested Ruins:** The ruins are protected by a swarm of small sharks; the Giant Shark is their leader.  
- **Shark‑Mimicry:** A lycanthropic NPC can transform into a giant shark, allowing a stealthy underwater approach.

---

**Bottom Line:** The 5 e Giant Shark is a straightforward, low‑CR water predator that uses a single bite attack and simple tactics. It’s ideal for early‑level sea or underwater encounters, and it can be expanded or tweaked to fit higher‑level stories. If you need a stronger version, swap in the Great White Shark or a 3.5 e Giant Shark with more damage and a few extra actions.

Appendix MM -B: Nonplayer Characters
This appendix contains statistics for various humanoid nonplayer characters (NPCs) that adventurers might encounter during a campaign, including lowly commoners and mighty archmages. These stat blocks can be used to represent both human and nonhuman NPCs.

Customizing NPCs
There are many easy ways to customize the NPCs in this appendix for your home campaign.
Racial Traits. You can add racial traits to an NPC. For example, a halfling druid might have a speed of 25 feet and the Lucky trait. Adding racial traits to an NPC doesn’t alter its challenge rating. For more on racial traits, see the Player’s Handbook.
Spell Swaps. One way to customize an NPC spellcaster is to replace one or more of its spells. You can substitute any spell on the NPC’s spell list with a different spell of the same level from the same spell list. Swapping spells in this manner doesn’t alter an NPC’s challenge rating.
Armor and Weapon Swaps. You can upgrade or downgrade an NPC’s armor, or add or switch weapons. Adjustments to Armor Class and damage can change an NPC’s challenge rating.
Magic Items. The more powerful an NPC, the more likely it has one or more magic items in its possession. An archmage, for example, might have a magic staff or wand, as well as one or more potions and scrolls. Giving an NPC a potent damage-dealing magic item could alter its challenge rating.

Appendix MM -B: Nonplayer Characters
This appendix contains statistics for various humanoid nonplayer characters (NPCs) that adventurers might encounter during a campaign, including lowly commoners and mighty archmages. These stat blocks can be used to represent both human and nonhuman NPCs.

Customizing NPCs
There are many easy ways to customize the NPCs in this appendix for your home campaign.
Racial Traits. You can add racial traits to an NPC. For example, a halfling druid might have a speed of 25 feet and the Lucky trait. Adding racial traits to an NPC doesn’t alter its challenge rating. For more on racial traits, see the Player’s Handbook.
Spell Swaps. One way to customize an NPC spellcaster is to replace one or more of its spells. You can substitute any spell on the NPC’s spell list with a different spell of the same level from the same spell list. Swapping spells in this manner doesn’t alter an NPC’s challenge rating.
Armor and Weapon Swaps. You can upgrade or downgrade an NPC’s armor, or add or switch weapons. Adjustments to Armor Class and damage can change an NPC’s challenge rating.
Magic Items. The more powerful an NPC, the more likely it has one or more magic items in its possession. An archmage, for example, might have a magic staff or wand, as well as one or more potions and scrolls. Giving an NPC a potent damage-dealing magic item could alter its challenge rating.

### Warhorse (Monster Manual, 5 e)

---

#### Attack

| Attack | Attack Bonus | Reach | Target | Damage |
|--------|--------------|-------|--------|--------|
| Hooves | +5 | 5 ft. | One creature | 2d6 + 3 bludgeoning |

The warhorse is a natural weapon; the damage is the same whether the rider is fighting or the warhorse is used on its own.

---

#### Trample

> **When the warhorse moves at least 20 ft. in a straight line and then makes a melee attack that hits, it can *trample* the target.**  
> The target must succeed on a DC 13 Strength saving throw or be knocked prone.  
> In addition, the target takes **1d6 bludgeoning damage** (no attack bonus, just a roll).

*Trample* is the warhorse’s only “special” ability.  It is used automatically when the warhorse performs a *charge* (the Charge action) and hits with its hooves.  It can also be used outside a formal charge if the DM allows the warhorse to move 20 ft. and then attack; the effect is the same.

---

## How to Use a Warhorse in Combat

| Situation | What the warhorse can do | Tips |
|-----------|------------------------|------|
| **Mounting a PC/NPC** | The rider gains the benefits of a normal mount: the rider can use their own action to attack or command the warhorse. | Use the “Mount” and “Rider” rules from the PHB.  The rider’s Attack action can be used to strike from the warhorse’s hooves. |
| **Charge** | Move 20 ft. (or more) and attack with hooves.  If it hits, Trample activates. | Charge deals the normal damage **plus the Trample damage**.  The target is knocked prone on a failed Strength save, giving advantage to the rider’s next attack. |
| **Stand‑alone** | The warhorse can fight on its own, making a Hooves attack every turn. | Useful for an NPC rider who wants to use the warhorse’s attack without the rider’s intervention. |
| **Defensive support** | The warhorse can use its high speed to keep distance or to block enemies. | If a creature tries to attack the rider, the warhorse can be commanded to use its natural armor and Hooves to deflect. |

### Combat Flow Example

1. **Action** – The rider orders the warhorse to charge.  
2. **Movement** – The warhorse moves 20 ft. toward the target.  
3. **Attack** – The warhorse makes its Hooves attack.  
   * If the attack hits:  
     * The target must make a DC 13 Strength save or be knocked prone.  
     * The target takes 1d6 bludgeoning (Trample).  
     * The rider now has an opportunity to strike a prone enemy with advantage.  
4. **Bonus Action** – The rider can use *Dash* or *Help* to aid allies.  
5. **Reposition** – The warhorse may use its high speed to keep its distance or to attack another target on a subsequent turn.

---

## Key Points to Remember

1. **Warhorse is a simple creature**—no spellcasting or complex tactics.  
2. **Trample** is its only special feature; it is effectively a built‑in Charge bonus.  
3. **Hooves** attack is the primary way to damage enemies.  
4. **Mounting rules** let a character use the warhorse’s attacks while riding it.  
5. **Speed 50 ft.** makes it a great scout or a fast line‑breaker in melee.  

That’s the essence of a warhorse in D&D 5e—quick, sturdy, and with one potent ability that turns a normal charge into a potentially devastating trample. Use it to keep the pressure on enemies, knock foes prone, and provide a solid, moving platform for your fighter or paladin.

user_input: What hapens if a Medium hobgoblin stands in a 5-foot-wide doorway?
reference_contexts: Space A creature’s space is the area in feet that it effectively controls in combat, not an expression of its physical dimensions. A typical Medium creature isn’t 5 feet wide, for example, but it does control a space that wide. If a Medium hobgoblin stands in a 5-foot-wide doorway, other creatures can’t get through unless the hobgoblin lets them. A creature’sspace also reflects the area it needs to fight effectively. For that reason, there’s a limit to the number of creatures that can surround another creature in combat. Assuming Medium combatants, eight creatures can fit in a 5-foot radius around another one. Because larger creatures take up more space, fewer of them can surround a creature. If five Large creatures crowd around a Medium or smaller one, there’s little room for anyone else. In contrast, as many as twenty Medium creatures can surround a Gargantuan one. Squeezing into a Smaller Space A creature can squeeze through a space that is large enough for a creature one size smaller than it. Thus, a Large creature can squeeze through a passage that’s only 5 feet wide. **Level 5 Barbarian: key combat perks**

| Feature | What it gives you | Notes |
|---------|-------------------|-------|
| **Unarmored Defense** | AC = 10 + Dexterity + Constitution | Applies while you’re not wearing armor.  It’s passive; you can’t “activate” it – it’s always your AC if you’re unarmored. |
| **Reckless Attack** | Advantage on melee weapon attack rolls that use Strength | Gives you +2 to the attack roll, but also grants disadvantage to all melee attack rolls **made against you** until the start of your next turn. |
| **Danger Sense** | Advantage on Dexterity saving throws against things you can see | Think of it as “pre‑sense” for traps, fire, etc. |
| **Fast Movement** | +10 ft to your speed | Adds a burst of mobility. |
| **Extra Attack** | Attack twice instead of once when you take the Attack action | You can use Reckless Attack on either or both of those attacks. |
| **Rage** | 2‑turn burst of melee damage bonus (+2d6) + advantage on Strength checks & saves; resistance to bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing | At 5th level you can use Rage twice per long rest (up from 1 at 2nd).  The damage bonus is +2d6 (increased from +1d6 at 4th). |
| **Strength Boost** | +2 to Strength (from 2nd level) | Gives higher damage rolls and better attack bonuses. |

**Interaction between Unarmored Defense & Reckless Attack**

* **No direct conflict** – Unarmored Defense simply sets your AC while you’re not wearing armor; it never changes when you use Reckless Attack.
* **Stacking effects** – You can use Reckless Attack on a turn while you’re benefiting from Unarmored Defense.  You get advantage on the melee attack roll(s) and you keep the AC from Unarmored Defense.  
  *If an enemy uses a melee attack against you, the disadvantage from Reckless Attack applies to them, but your AC is still 10 + Dex + Con.*  
* **Strategic trade‑off** – Reckless Attack can help you hit enemies (and thus trigger your Rage damage bonus more often), but it also makes you an easier target for the same enemies.  You’ll often use it against foes that can’t hit you easily or when you’re in the middle of a melee fight where the extra damage matters more than the extra vulnerability.

In short, at level 5 you can hit twice with advantage, move faster, have a solid AC without armor, and still benefit from your Rage damage and resistances—all while knowing that a Reckless Attack will both help your attacks and make you slightly more vulnerable to the enemies that target you.

Unarmored Defense gives an AC of 10 + Dexterity modifier + Constitution modifier while not wearing heavy armor, and a shield can still be used. Reckless Attack, available from 2nd level, lets the Barbarian take advantage on melee attacks using Strength for the first attack of the turn, but grants advantage to attackers against the Barbarian until the next turn.

**Bard College (5th Edition)**  

Bards in *Dungeons & Dragons* 5th e are a versatile class that blends spellcasting, music, and lore. At 3rd level, a bard chooses a *Bard College*—a specialized path that shapes their abilities, spells, and thematic focus. The subclasses introduced in the *Player’s Handbook*, *Xanathar’s Guide to Everything*, *Tasha’s Cauldron of Everything*, and *Unearthed Arcana* are:

| College | Core Concept | Key Features |
|---------|--------------|--------------|
| **College of Lore** | Scholar of history, secrets, and versatility. | *Song of Rest* (extra healing), *Additional Magical Secrets* (pick spells from any class), *Cutting Words* (negate attack rolls, saves, or spell checks). |
| **College of Valor** | Warrior bard, inspiring courage. | *Battle Magic* (spellcasting before or after attack), *Bonus Proficiencies* (medium armor, shields), *Inspiring Leader* (temporary HP). |
| **College of Glamour** | Enchanter of the Fey, charismatic performance. | *Mantle of Inspiration* (temporary HP & movement), *Fey Presence* (charismatic effects), *Enthralling Performance* (charismatic charm). |
| **College of Swords** | Bladed bard, swashbuckling flair. | *Blade Flourish* (attacks with extra effects), *Extra Attack* at 6th level, *Fighting Style* choice. |
| **College of Whispers** | Manipulator of fear and secrets. | *Psychic Blades*, *Words of Terror* (fear & damage), *Mantle of Whispers* (use enemy’s secrets). |
| **College of Creation** (UA) | Bard that turns ideas into matter. | *Craft* (create items), *Creative Inspiration*, *Creation Touch* (materializing). |
| **College of Eloquence** (UA) | Master debater and speechmaker. | *Unfailing Eloquence*, *Unshakable Faith* (advantage on saving throws). |
| **College of the Muse** (UA) | Bard who can channel inspiration into magic. | *Muse* (gain temporary spell slots), *Master of Inspiration*. |

### How a Bard College Works

1. **Class Features**  
   At 3rd level, the bard chooses a college, gaining its unique features (often providing new spells, abilities, or proficiencies).  

2. **Spellcasting**  
   Bards have a full list of spells at all levels. Colleges let you access spells from other classes (*Additional Magical Secrets*), or provide thematic spell slots.  

3. **Role‑playing**  
   Colleges give flavor: a Lore bard might spend time in archives, a Glamour bard at courts, a Valor bard on the front lines, etc.  

4. **Progression**  
   Each college offers tiered benefits at 3rd, 6th, 10th, 14th, and 18th levels, enhancing combat, support, or utility in line with the college’s theme.  

5. **Interaction with the Party**  
   Bards are known for **Bardic Inspiration**, a dice bonus to allies. Colleges can augment this (e.g., *Inspiring Leader* gives temporary hit points, *Cutting Words* negates enemy rolls).  

### Choosing a College

- **Playstyle** – Do you want to support, heal, damage, or control?
- **Narrative** – Which background or setting fits the college?
- **Party Composition** – What does the group lack? (e.g., a college that offers extra healing or crowd control)

**Bottom line:**  
A Bard College is a 5e subclass that defines a bard’s specialization, providing thematic abilities, new spells, and character flavor, and shaping how the bard contributes to the party.

**Song of Rest**  
*Class:* Bard  
*Level:* 3rd (PHB, p. 53)  

---

### 1. What is it?

A special bardic ability that lets allies add extra hit points whenever they spend hit dice during a *short rest*. It is **not** a spell, nor does it require the bard to spend any resources.

---

### 2. How does it help during a short rest?

When a creature that can hear the bard spends a hit die to regain hit points, that creature can roll an extra die (the “bardic‑inspiration die”) and add the result to the hit points it has just regained. The feature can trigger **any number of times** during the short rest – every time a creature spends a hit die and is able to hear the bard.

---

### 3. Hit‑point bonus by bard level

| Bard level | Size of the extra die |
|------------|-----------------------|
| 3rd‑4th    | d6 |
| 5th‑8th    | d8 |
| 9th‑12th   | d10 |
| 13th‑20th  | d12 |

So at 3rd level the bonus is 1–6 HP, at 5th level 1–8 HP, and so on.

---

### 4. Difference from Bardic Inspiration

| Feature | What it gives | When it can be used |
|---------|---------------|---------------------|
| **Bardic Inspiration** | A die (d6 → d8 → d10 → d12) that an ally can add to an ability check, attack roll, or saving throw. | Any time an ally can hear the bard (not tied to a rest). |
| **Song of Rest** | An extra die added to hit points gained from spending hit dice during a short rest. | Only during short rests, and only when a creature spends a hit die. |

Song of Rest **does not** require a Bardic Inspiration die to be expended; the bard can roll the die freely each time the trigger occurs.

---

### 5. Can other classes use it?

No. It is a **bard class feature** (no subclass prerequisite).

---

### 6. Exact wording (PHB, p. 53)

> **Song of Rest**  
> When you or a creature that can hear you regains hit points by spending hit dice during a short rest, that creature can roll a bardic inspiration die and add it to the hit points regained. The die you roll is a d6 at 3rd level. The die increases to a d8 at 5th level, to a d10 at 9th level, and to a d12 at 13th level.

---

### 7. Does it require the bard to spend hit dice?

No. The bard does **not** need to spend any hit dice or any other resource to use the feature. It simply allows an ally to roll an extra die whenever they spend a hit die during the short rest.

---

### 8. Can the bard help allies who are *not* healing?

No. The effect is tied specifically to the moment a creature *spends a hit die to regain hit points*. It does not apply to other kinds of healing (e.g., spells) or to non‑healing benefits.

---

### 9. Prerequisites

- **Class:** Bard  
- **Level:** 3rd (no subclass requirement)

---

### 10. Interaction with other bard features

| Feature | Interaction |
|---------|-------------|
| **Countercharm** | No effect. Countercharm provides a bonus to saving throws, not to hit points. |
| **Magical Secrets** | No effect. Magical Secrets lets you learn extra spells, not affect Song of Rest. |
| **Bardic Inspiration** | The die used for Song of Rest is the same die size that Bardic Inspiration uses, but it is rolled independently and does **not** consume an inspiration die. |

---

### 11. Applies to all friendly creatures who can hear the bard?

Yes. *Any* creature that can hear the bard and is spending hit dice during a short rest can benefit. There is no limit on how many creatures can benefit in a single short rest.

---

### 12. How many times per short rest?

Unlimited, as many times as the trigger occurs. If, for example, three different allies each spend a hit die during the same short rest, each of them can roll the extra die.

---

### 13. Limit on number of creatures that can benefit

No explicit limit. The only restrictions are that the creature must be able to hear the bard and must be spending a hit die during the short rest.

---

### 14. Difference between the d6, d8, d10, and d12 versions

The difference is purely the size of the extra die added to healing:

- **d6** → 1–6 HP
- **d8** → 1–8 HP
- **d10** → 1–10 HP
- **d12** → 1–12 HP

The progression is tied to the bard’s level as shown in the table above.

---

### 15. How the feature scales with level

The die size scales at the following levels: 3, 5, 9, 13. After 13th level it stays at d12 for the rest of the game.

---

### 16. Can the bard use it during a long rest?

No. The feature explicitly states *“during a short rest.”* It does not function during a long rest.

---

### 17. Does the feature require the bard to be a bard?

Yes. Only bards can choose this feature; it is part of the Bard class, not a multiclass or feat option.

---

### 18. Recap of the text

> **Song of Rest**  
> When you or a creature that can hear you regains hit points by spending hit dice during a short rest, that creature can roll a bardic inspiration die and add it to the hit points regained. The die you roll is a d6 at 3rd level. The die increases to a d8 at 5th level, to a d10 at 9th level, and to a d12 at 13th level.  

That is the complete, unabridged text from the Player’s Handbook.

**Jack of All Trades**  
*Bard feature – level 2*  

> “You can add **half your proficiency bonus** (rounded down) to any **ability check** that doesn’t already include your proficiency bonus.”

### How it works

| Level | Proficiency bonus | Half‑bonus you add (rounded down) |
|-------|-------------------|-----------------------------------|
| 2‑3   | +2                | +1                                |
| 4‑5   | +3                | +1                                |
| 6‑7   | +3                | +1                                |
| 8‑9   | +4                | +2                                |
| 10‑11 | +4                | +2                                |
| 12‑13 | +5                | +2                                |
| 14‑15 | +5                | +2                                |
| 16‑17 | +6                | +3                                |
| 18‑19 | +6                | +3                                |
| 20    | +6                | +3                                |

**Key points**

1. **What counts as an ability check?**  
   – Any check that uses an ability score: skill checks, tool checks, or any “Strength / Dexterity / Intelligence / Wisdom / Charisma check” that isn’t a saving throw.  
   – The feature does *not* apply to saving throws (the PHB defines them separately) or to checks that already use your proficiency bonus.

2. **When does it apply?**  
   – From 2nd level onward, the bard can add the half‑bonus *to any such check* on a given roll.  
   – It’s a constant bonus, not a resource that depletes.

3. **Practical effect**  
   - **Unproficient checks**:  
     A level‑2 bard with Intelligence 12 (+1) faces a DC 10 Arcana check.  
     *Normal*: 1 + roll = +1 on average.  
     *With Jack of All Trades*: 1 + roll + 1 = **+2** on average.  
   - **Proficient checks**:  
     If the bard is proficient in the skill, he already gets the full proficiency bonus (+2 at level 2).  
     Jack of All Trades *does not* add another bonus to that check.  
   - **Tool or other checks**:  
     The same +1 (or +2, +3, etc., at higher levels) applies to, say, a Sleight of Hand check on a tool you’re not trained in, a Strength check to break a door, or a Wisdom check for a Perception test you’re not skilled at.

4. **Why it matters**  
   – Bards often have many skills and may not be proficient in every one of them.  
   – Jack of All Trades gives them a modest but constant “tweak” to all their otherwise weak checks, making them more versatile and reliable throughout the game.

### Bottom line

From level 2, a bard can, on every roll, add *half* of his proficiency bonus (rounded down) to any ability check that doesn’t already include proficiency. The bonus grows as the bard’s proficiency bonus increases, offering a persistent, low‑cost advantage on a wide range of checks.
reference: In the bard class features table, the "Jack of All Trades" feature is listed at 2nd level alongside Song of Rest (d6). This placement indicates that the feature becomes available when a bard reaches 2nd level. The detailed description, found in the second context segment, explains that starting at 2nd level, a bard can add half of their proficiency bonus, rounded down, to any ability check they make that does not already include their proficiency bonus. This means that for every ability check—such as a Dexterity (Acrobatics) check, a Charisma (Persuasion) check, or a Wisdom (Perception) check—a bard can boost the roll by this additional amount, provided the check is not one where proficiency is already applied. The feature does not grant proficiency to checks that already benefit from it; it simply supplements checks that are otherwise unproficient. Thus, "Jack of All Trades" provides a consistent, level‑based bonus to a bard’s versatility in skill checks, reinforcing the bard’s role as a jack‑of‑all‑trades character.

**Use the College of Lore’s “Cutting Words” feature.**  
When you’re a Bard (College of Lore) you gain the *Cutting Words* ability at 6th level. It works like this:

1. **Spend a Bardic Inspiration die** (from your Bard levels) as a reaction.  
2. **Choose the enemy’s attack roll** (or ability check/damage roll) and subtract the die roll from that number.  
3. The attack is made **after you apply the subtraction**; if the result is 0 or less, the attack automatically misses.

Because it’s a reaction, you can use it right after the enemy declares their attack but before the roll is made, effectively “cutting off” the attack. You only need the Bardic Inspiration die—no other bonus or effect is required.

*Quick note:*  
- You must have at least 6 Bard levels (or the equivalent multiclass level) to have Cutting Words.  
- You need an unused Bardic Inspiration die at the time you use it.  
- The effect is purely a reduction of the attack roll; it doesn’t stop the enemy’s turn entirely.  

That’s the standard way a barbarian‑bard hybrid can stop or reduce an enemy’s attack with Bardic Inspiration.

**Using a Bardic Inspiration die to lower an enemy’s attack roll**

Only a Bard who belongs to the **College of Lore** (or gains the same feature from a multiclass or feat) can do this.  
The feature is called **Cutting Words** (PHB p. 63, Xanathar’s, etc.):

> As a reaction, when a creature you can see makes an attack roll, an ability check, or a damage roll, you can expend a Bardic Inspiration die and subtract its value from that roll.

So the steps are:

1. **Wait for the enemy’s attack roll.**  
2. **Use your reaction** and expend a Bardic Inspiration die.  
3. **Roll the die** and subtract that number from the enemy’s attack roll.  
4. The die is consumed and the reaction is used.

This ability can only be used on enemies you can see and only when they are making an attack roll (or ability check/damage roll, per the feature). If you are not a College‑of‑Lore bard, you cannot reduce an enemy’s attack roll with a Bardic Inspiration die.
